original: namaḥ savitre nairṛtye vāruṇe tapanaṃ punaḥ /
analyzed: namaḥ savitre nairṛtye vāruṇe tapanam punar
translated: Salutations to Savita (the impeller) in the southwest, and to Tapana (the scorching one) in the west.

original: vāyavye tu bhagaṃ nyasya punaḥ punarathārcayet // / //
analyzed: vāyavye tu bhagam nyasya punar punar atha arcayet
translated: Having placed Bhaga (the giver of fortune) in the northwest, one should worship again and again.

original: mārtaṇḍamuttare viṣṇum īśāne vinyasetsadā /🔽gandhamālyaphalairbhakṣyaiḥ sthaṇḍile pūjayettataḥ // / //🔽dvijāya sodakumbhaṃ ca ghṛtapātraṃ hiraṇmayam /
analyzed: mārtaṇḍam uttare viṣṇum īśāne vinyaset sadā  gandha mālya phalaiḥ bhakṣyaiḥ sthaṇḍile pūjayet tatas  dvijāya sa udakumbham ca ghṛta pātram hiraṇmayam
translated: In the north, one should always place Martanda (the sun) and Vishnu, and in the northeast, one should always place Shiva.🔽Then, on the ground, one should worship with scents, garlands, fruits, and edibles.🔽To a Brahmin, one should cause to be made, according to one's ability, a water pot with water, a ghee vessel made of gold,

analyzed: kamalam ca yathāśaktyā kārayitvā nivedayet
translated: and a lotus, and offer them.

analyzed: candana udaka puṣpaiḥ ca devāya arghyam nyaset bhuvi
translated: With sandalwood water and flowers, one should offer arghya to the Lord on the ground.

analyzed: viśvāya viśvarūpāya viśva dhāmne svayambhuve
translated: To the universe, to the one with universal form, to the abode of the universe, to the self-existent one,

analyzed: namaḥ nanta namaḥ dhātre ṛk sāma yajuṣām pate
translated: Salutations to the infinite, salutations to the creator, to the lord of the Rig, Sama and Yajur Vedas.

original: anena vidhinā sarvaṃ māsi māsi samācaret /
analyzed: anena vidhinā sarvam māsi māsi samācaret
translated: One should perform all this according to this procedure every month.

original: vatsarānte 'thavā kuryāt sarvaṃ dvādaśadhā naraḥ // / //🔽saṃvatsarānte ghṛtapāyasena saṃtarpya vahniṃ dvijapuṃgavāṃśca /
analyzed: vatsara ante kuryāt sarvam dvādaśadhā naraḥ  saṃvatsara ante ghṛta pāyasena saṃtarpya vahnim dvija puṃgavān ca
translated: At the end of the year, or a man may do all this twelve times.🔽At the end of the year, having satisfied the fire and the best of Brahmins with ghee and milk pudding,

analyzed: kumbhān punar dvādaśa dhenu yuktān sa ratna hairaṇmaya padma yuktān
translated: One should again give twelve pots along with cows, along with gold and jeweled lotuses.

original: payasvinīḥ śīlavatīśca dadyād dharmaiḥ śṛṅgaiḥ raupyakhuraiśca yuktāḥ /
analyzed: payasvinīḥ śīlavatīḥ ca dadyāt dharmaiḥ śṛṅgaiḥ raupya khuraiḥ ca yuktāḥ
translated: One should give cows that are full of milk, virtuous, with horns, hooves and udders made of silver.

original: gāvo 'ṣṭa vā sapta sakāṃsyadohā mālyāmbarā vā caturo 'pyaśaktaḥ /
analyzed: gāvaḥ ṣṭa vā sapta sakāṃsya dohāḥ mālya ambarāḥ vā caturaḥ pi a śaktaḥ
translated: Eight or seven cows with brass milk pails, or four cows with garlands and clothes, if unable.

original: daurgatyayuktaḥ kapilāmathaikāṃ nivedayedbrāhmaṇapuṃgavāya // / //🔽haimīṃ ca dadyātpṛthivīṃ saśeṣām ākārya rūpyāmatha vā ca tāmrīm /
analyzed: daurgatya yuktaḥ kapilām atha ekām nivedayet brāhmaṇa puṃgavāya  haimīm ca dadyāt pṛthivīm saśeṣām ākārya rūpyām atha vā ca tāmrīm
translated: If unable, one should offer a tawny cow to the best of Brahmins.🔽One should also give a golden replica of the earth, or a silver or copper one.

original: paiṣṭīmaśaktaḥ pratimāṃ vidhāya sauvarṇasūryeṇa samaṃ pradadyāt /
analyzed: paiṣṭīm aśaktaḥ pratimām vidhāya sauvarṇa sūryeṇa samam pradadyāt
translated: If unable, one should make a clay replica and give it along with a golden sun.

original: na vittaśāṭhyaṃ puruṣo 'tra kuryāt kurvannadho yāti na saṃśayo 'tra // / //
analyzed: na vitta śāṭhyam puruṣaḥ tra kuryāt kurvan adhas yāti na saṃśayaḥ tra
translated: A man should not be miserly with wealth here. By being so, he certainly goes down.

analyzed: yāvat mahendra pramukhaiḥ nagendraiḥ pṛthvā ca sapta abdhi yutā iha tiṣṭhet
translated: As long as the great mountains headed by Mahendra stand on the earth with the seven oceans,

original: tāvatsa gandharvagaṇair aśeṣaiḥ sampūjyate nārada nākapṛṣṭhe // / //
analyzed: tāvat sa gandharva gaṇaiḥ aśeṣaiḥ sampūjyate nārada nāka pṛṣṭhe
translated: For that long, O Narada, he is worshipped by all the hosts of Gandharvas on the peak of heaven.

analyzed: tatas tu karma kṣayam āpya saptadvīpā adhipaḥ syāt kula śīla yuktaḥ
translated: Then, having attained the exhaustion of karma, he becomes the lord of the seven islands, endowed with family and good conduct,

analyzed: sṛṣṭeḥ mukhe vyaṅga vapuḥ sa bhāryaḥ prabhūta putra anvaya vandita aṅghriḥ
translated: At the beginning of creation, with an unimpaired body, with his wife, with his feet worshipped by many sons and relatives.

original: iti paṭhati śṛṇoti vātha bhaktyā vidhimakhilaṃ ravisaṃkramasya puṇyam /
analyzed: iti paṭhati śṛṇoti vā atha bhaktyā vidhim akhilam ravi saṃkramasya puṇyam
translated: He who reads or listens with devotion to the entire auspicious procedure of the transit of the sun,

original: matimapi ca dadāti so 'pi devair amarapaterbhavane prapūjyate ca // / //
analyzed: matim api ca dadāti saḥ devaiḥ amarapateḥ bhavane prapūjyate ca
translated: And gives even a thought about it, he is worshipped in the abode of the lord of the immortals by the gods.

analyzed: matsyapurāṇa
translated: Matsya Purana

analyzed: nandikeśvaraḥ uvāca
translated: Nandikeśvara said:

analyzed: śṛṇu nārada vakṣyāmi viṣṇoḥ vratam anuttamam
translated: Listen, O Narada, I shall tell you about Vishnu's excellent vow,

analyzed: vibhūtidvādaśī nāma sarva deva namaskṛtam
translated: Known as Vibhuti Dvādaśī, revered by all gods.

analyzed: kārttike caitra vaiśākhe mārgaśīrṣe ca phālgune
translated: In Kārttika, Caitra, Vaiśākha, Mārgaśīrṣa, and Phālguna,

original: āṣāḍhe vā daśamyāṃ tu śuklāyāṃ laghubhuṅnaraḥ /
analyzed: āṣāḍhe vā daśamyām tu śuklāyām laghu bhuj naraḥ
translated: In the month of Ashadha, on the tenth day of the bright fortnight, a person should eat lightly,

analyzed: kṛtvā sāyantanīm saṃdhyām gṛhṇīyāt niyamam budhaḥ
translated: Perform the evening sandhya, and the wise one should take up the vow.

analyzed: ekādaśyām nirāhāraḥ samabhyarcya janārdanam
translated: On the eleventh day, fasting, having worshipped Janardana,

analyzed: dvādaśyām dvija saṃyuktaḥ kariṣye bhojanam vibho
translated: On the twelfth day, O Lord, I shall have a meal with the Brahmins.

original: tadavighnena me yātu saphalaṃ syācca keśava /
analyzed: tat avighnena me yātu saphalam syāt ca keśava
translated: May that be successful for me without obstacles, O Keshava.

original: namo nārāyaṇāyeti vācyaṃ ca svapatā niśi // / //
analyzed: namaḥ nārāyaṇāya iti vācyam ca svapatā niśi
translated: One should say Salutations to Narayana while going to sleep at night.

analyzed: tatas prabhāte utthāya kṛta snāna japaḥ śuciḥ
translated: Then, rising at dawn, having bathed and performed japa, being pure,

original: pūjayetpuṇḍarīkākṣaṃ śuklamālyānulepanaiḥ // / //🔽vibhūtaye namaḥ pādāv aśokāya ca jānunī /
analyzed: pūjayet puṇḍarīkākṣam śukla mālya anulepanaiḥ  vibhūtaye namaḥ pādau aśokāya ca jānunī
translated: One should worship the lotus-eyed one with white garlands and unguents.🔽Salutations to Vibhuta for the feet, to Ashoka for the knees,

original: namaḥ śivāyetyūrū ca viśvamūrte namaḥ kaṭim // / //
analyzed: namaḥ śivāya iti ūrū ca viśvamūrte namaḥ kaṭim
translated: Salutations to Shiva for the thighs, to the universal form for the hips.

original: kandarpāya namo meḍhram ādityāya namaḥ karau /
analyzed: kandarpāya namaḥ meḍhram ādityāya namaḥ karau
translated: Salutations to Kandarpa for the penis, to Aditya for the hands,

analyzed: dāmodarāya iti udaram vāsudevāya ca stanau
translated: Salutations to Damodara for the belly, to Vasudeva for the breasts.

analyzed: mādhavāya iti uraḥ viṣṇoḥ kaṇṭham utkaṇṭhine namaḥ
translated: Salutations to Madhava for the chest of Vishnu, to the longing one for the throat,

analyzed: śrīdharāya mukham keśān keśavāya iti nārada
translated: Salutations to Sridhara for the face, to Keshava for the hair, O Narada.

analyzed: pṛṣṭham śārṅgadharāya iti śravaṇau varadāya vai
translated: The back is for the wielder of Sharnga bow, the ears for the bestower of boons,

analyzed: sva nāmnā śaṅkha cakra asi gadā jalaja pāṇaye
translated: The hands holding conch, discus, sword, club and lotus are to be worshipped with one's own name.

analyzed: śiraḥ sarvātmane brahman namaḥ iti abhipūjayet
translated: O Brahmin, the head is for the universal soul. Thus one should worship.

original: matsyamutpalasaṃyuktaṃ haimaṃ kṛtvā tu śaktitaḥ /🔽udakumbhasamāyuktam agrataḥ sthāpayedbudhaḥ // / //
analyzed: matsyam utpala saṃyuktam haimam kṛtvā tu śaktitas  udakumbha samāyuktam agratas sthāpayet budhaḥ
translated: Having made a golden image of the fish along with a lotus flower according to one's ability,🔽The wise one should place it in front along with a water pot.

analyzed: guḍa pātram tilaiḥ yuktam sita vastra abhiveṣṭitam
translated: A vessel of jaggery along with sesamum seeds, wrapped in white cloth,

analyzed: rātrau jāgaraṇam kuryāt itihāsa kathā ādinā
translated: One should keep awake at night with stories and other narrations.

analyzed: prabhātāyām tu śarvaryām brāhmaṇāya kuṭumbine
translated: In the morning, to a householder Brahmin,

analyzed: sa kāñcana utpalam devam sa udakumbham nivedayet
translated: One should offer the god along with gold and blue lotus, along with a water pot.

original: yathā na mucyase deva sadā sarvavibhūtibhiḥ /
analyzed: yathā na mucyase deva sadā sarva vibhūtibhiḥ
translated: Just as you are never separated from all the riches, O God,

analyzed: tathā mām uddhara aśeṣa duḥkha saṃsāra kardamāt
translated: In the same way, lift me out of all miseries and the mud of worldly existence.

original: daśāvatārarūpāṇi pratimāsaṃ kramānmune /🔽dattātreyaṃ tathā vyāsam utpalena samanvitam /
analyzed: daśa avatāra rūpāṇi pratimāsam kramāt mune  dattātreyam tathā vyāsam utpalena samanvitam
translated: O sage, the ten incarnations in order every month,🔽Dattatreya and Vyasa along with the blue lotus,

analyzed: dadyāt evam samāḥ yāvat pāṣaṇḍān abhivarjayet
translated: One should offer in this way until the end of the year, avoiding heretics.

analyzed: samāpya evam yathāśaktyā dvādaśa dvādaśīḥ punar
translated: Having completed this according to one's ability, one should again observe twelve Dvadashi vows,

analyzed: saṃvatsara ante lavaṇaparvatena samanvitām
translated: At the end of the year, he should give a bed along with a salt mountain,

analyzed: śayyām dadyāt muni śreṣṭha gurave dhenu saṃyutām
translated: O best of sages, to the guru, along with a cow.

original: grāmaṃ ca śaktimāndadyāt kṣetraṃ vā bhavanānvitam /
analyzed: grāmam ca śaktimān dadyāt kṣetram vā bhavana anvitam
translated: If able, he should give a village, a field with a house,

analyzed: gurum sampūjya vidhivat vastra alaṃkāra bhūṣaṇaiḥ
translated: and having duly worshipped the guru with clothes, ornaments, and decorations,

analyzed: anyān api yathāśaktyā bhojayitvā dvijottamān
translated: he should feed other excellent Brahmins according to his ability,

analyzed: tarpayet ratna ogha dhana saṃcayaiḥ
translated: and satisfy them with gifts of clothes, cows, jewels, and wealth.

analyzed: alpa vittaḥ yathāśaktyā stokam stokam samācaret
translated: One with little wealth should perform little by little according to his ability.

analyzed: yaḥ ca api atīva niḥsvaḥ syāt bhaktimān mādhavam prati
translated: One who is extremely poor but has devotion towards Madhava,

original: puṣpārcanavidhānena sa kuryādvatsaradvayam // / //🔽anena vidhinā yastu vibhūtidvādaśīvratam /
analyzed: puṣpa arcana vidhānena sa kuryāt vatsara dvayam  anena vidhinā yaḥ tu vibhūti dvādaśīvratam
translated: he should perform for two years by the method of flower worship.🔽One who performs the Vibhuti Dvādaśī Vrata by this method,

analyzed: kuryāt pāpa vinirmuktaḥ pitṝṇām tārayet śatam
translated: becomes free from sins and liberates a hundred ancestors.

analyzed: janmanām śata sāhasram na śoka phala bhāj bhavet
translated: For a hundred thousand births, he does not experience the fruits of sorrow.

original: na ca vyādhirbhavettasya na dāridryaṃ na bandhanam /
analyzed: na ca vyādhiḥ bhavet tasya na dāridryam na bandhanam
translated: He does not suffer from diseases, poverty, or bondage.

original: vaiṣṇavo vātha śaivo vā bhavejjanmani janmani // / //
analyzed: vaiṣṇavaḥ vā atha śaivaḥ vā bhavet janmani janmani
translated: In birth after birth, he becomes a devotee of Vishnu or Shiva.

analyzed: yāvat yuga sahasrāṇām śatam aṣṭa uttaram bhavet
translated: As long as one thousand and eight hundred yugas pass,

analyzed: tāvat svarge vaset brahman bhūpatiḥ ca punar bhavet
translated: for so long one dwells in heaven, O Brahmin, and becomes a king again.

analyzed: matsyapurāṇa
translated: Matsya Purana

analyzed: nandikeśvaraḥ uvāca
translated: Nandikeśvara said

analyzed: purā rathaṃtare kalpe rājā āsīt puṣpavāhanaḥ
translated: In the past, in the Rathantara Kalpa, there was a king named Puṣpavāhana.

analyzed: nāmnā lokeṣu vikhyātaḥ tejasā sūrya saṃnibhaḥ
translated: He was famous in the worlds by that name, and his splendor was like that of the sun.

analyzed: tapasā tasya tuṣṭena caturvaktreṇa nārada
translated: O Nārada, by his austerities, the four-faced one was pleased with him.

analyzed: kamalam kāñcanam dattam yathā kāma gamam mune
translated: O sage, he gave him a golden lotus that could go wherever he wished.

analyzed: lokaiḥ samastaiḥ nagara vāsibhiḥ sahitaḥ nṛpaḥ
translated: The king, along with all the people and the city-dwellers,

analyzed: dvīpāni sura lokam ca yatheṣṭam vyacarat tadā
translated: wandered as he pleased to the islands and the world of the gods.

analyzed: kalpa ādau saptamam dvīpam tasya puṣkara vāsinaḥ
translated: At the beginning of the kalpa, the seventh island of that lotus-dweller,

analyzed: loke ca pūjitam yasmāt puṣkaradvīpam ucyate
translated: since it is worshipped in the world, is called Puṣkara Dvīpa.

analyzed: devena brahmaṇā dattam yānam asya yatas mbujam
translated: Since the lotus vehicle was given to him by the god Brahmā,

analyzed: puṣpavāhanam iti āhuḥ tasmāt tam deva dānavāḥ
translated: therefore the gods and demons call him Puṣpavāhana.

analyzed: na agamyam asya asti jagattraye brahma ambuja sthasya tapaḥ nubhāvāt
translated: By the power of his austerities, while seated on Brahmā's lotus, there is nothing in the three worlds that is inaccessible to him.

analyzed: patnī ca tasya apratimā muni indra nārī sahasraiḥ abhitas bhinandyā
translated: And his wife was incomparable, O lord of sages, being honored by thousands of women,

original: nāmnā ca lāvaṇyavatī babhūva sā pārvatīveṣṭatamā bhavasya // / //
analyzed: nāmnā ca lāvaṇyavatī babhūva sā pārvatī veṣṭatamā bhavasya
translated: And her name was Lāvaṇyavatī, she was most beloved of Bhava (Śiva) like Pārvatī.

analyzed: tasya ātmajānām ayutam babhūva dharma ātmanām agrya dhanurdharāṇām
translated: He had ten thousand sons, of righteous nature, foremost archers,

analyzed: tat ātmanaḥ sarvam avekṣya rājā muhur muhur vismayam āsasāda
translated: Seeing all that about himself, the king repeatedly marveled.

original: so 'bhyāgataṃ vīkṣya munipravīraṃ prācetasaṃ vākyamidaṃ babhāṣe // / //🔽kasmādvibhūtir amalāmaramartyapūjyā jātā ca sarvavijitāmarasundarīṇām /
analyzed: saḥ bhyāgatam vīkṣya muni pravīram prācetasam vākyam idam babhāṣe  kasmāt vibhūtiḥ amala amara martya pūjyā jātā ca sarva vijita amara sundarīṇām
translated: Seeing the best of sages Prācetas come, he spoke these words:🔽Why has this immaculate glory arisen, worshiped by gods and mortals,

original: bhāryā mamālpatapasā paritoṣitena dattaṃ mamāmbujagṛhaṃ ca munīndra dhātrā // / //
analyzed: bhāryā mama alpa tapasā paritoṣitena dattam mama ambuja gṛham ca muni indra dhātrā
translated: And why has the creator, the lord of sages, satisfied by my little austerities, given me as wife the most beautiful woman in the world,

analyzed: yasmin praviṣṭam api koṭi śatam nṛpāṇām sa amātya kuñjara ratha ogha jana āvṛtānām
translated: In which, even though a hundred million kings with their ministers, elephants, chariots, and people have entered,

original: no lakṣyate kva gatamambaramadhya indus tārāgaṇairiva gataḥ paritaḥ sphuradbhiḥ // / //
analyzed: no lakṣyate kva gatam ambara madhye induḥ tārā gaṇaiḥ iva gataḥ paritas sphuradbhiḥ
translated: The moon is not seen anywhere in the middle of the sky, as if it has gone surrounded by the shining stars.

analyzed: tasmāt kim anya jananī jaṭhara udbhavena dharma ādikam kṛtam aśeṣa phala āpti hetuḥ
translated: Therefore, what else is to be done by being born from the womb of another woman? Dharma and other things have been done, the cause of attaining all fruits.

original: bhagavanmayātha tanayair athavānayāpi bhadraṃ yadetadakhilaṃ kathaya pracetaḥ // / //
analyzed: bhagavat mayā atha tanayaiḥ athavā anayā api bhadram yat etat akhilam kathaya pracetaḥ
translated: Blessed one, tell us all this, O Prachetas, about what happened to you, your sons, and this lady.

analyzed: muniḥ abhyadhāt atha bhava antaritam samīkṣya pṛthvīpateḥ prasabham adbhuta hetu vṛttam
translated: The sage then, seeing the king's extraordinary conduct in a past life, said:

original: janmābhavattava tu lubdhakule 'tighore jātastvamapyanudinaṃ kila pāpakārī // / //
analyzed: janma abhavat tava tu lubdha kule ti ghore jātaḥ tvam api anudinam kila pāpa kārī
translated: Your birth was in a very terrible hunter's family, and you were a sinner day by day.

analyzed: vapuḥ api abhūt tava punar puruṣa aṅga saṃdhiḥ durgandhi sattva bhujaga āvaraṇam samantāt
translated: Your body became again a human body, covered all around with the smell of flesh-eating serpents.

original: na ca te suhṛn na sutabandhujano na tātas tv ādṛksvasā na jananī ca tadābhiśastā // / //
analyzed: na ca te suhṛd na suta bandhu janaḥ na tātaḥ tu ādṛś svasā na jananī ca tadā abhiśastā
translated: You had no friend, no son, no relative, no father, no sister, no mother who would look after you.

original: abhisaṃgatā paramabhīṣṭatamā vimukhī mahīśa tava yoṣidiyam /
analyzed: abhisaṃgatā param abhīṣṭatamā vimukhī mahīśa tava yoṣit iyam
translated: O king, this woman who is most dear to you and whom you love, has been rejected by you.

analyzed: abhūt anāvṛṣṭiḥ atīva raudrā kadācid āhāra nimittam asmin
translated: There was once a very terrible drought in this world, due to lack of food.

original: kṣutpīḍitenātha tadā na kiṃcid āsāditaṃ dhānyaphalāmiṣādyam // / //
analyzed: kṣudh pīḍitena atha tadā na kiṃcid āsāditam dhānya phala āmiṣa ādyam
translated: When afflicted by hunger, nothing was obtained, such as grain, fruit, or meat.

analyzed: atha abhidṛṣṭam mahat ambuja āḍhyam sarovaram paṅka parīta rodhaḥ
translated: Then a large lake was seen, full of large lotuses, with its banks covered with mud.

original: padmānyathādāya tato bahūni gataḥ puraṃ vaidiśanāmadheyam // / //
analyzed: padmāni atha ādāya tatas bahūni gataḥ puram vaidiśa nāmadheyam
translated: Then taking many lotuses, you went to the city named Vaidiśa.

original: tanmaulyalābhāya puraṃ samastaṃ bhrāntaṃ tvayāśeṣam ahas tadāsīt /
analyzed: tad maulya lābhāya puram samastam bhrāntam tvayā aśeṣam ahar tadā āsīt
translated: For the sake of getting their price, you wandered through the entire city that day.

original: kretā na kaścitkamaleṣu jātaḥ śrānto bhṛśaṃ kṣutparipīḍitaśca // / //
analyzed: kretā na kaścid kamaleṣu jātaḥ śrāntaḥ bhṛśam kṣudh paripīḍitaḥ ca
translated: But no buyer was found for the lotuses. You became very tired and were greatly afflicted by hunger.

analyzed: upaviṣṭaḥ tvam ekasmin sa bhāryaḥ bhavana aṅgaṇe
translated: You sat down with your wife in the courtyard of a house.

translated: I will describe the seven continents as they are in Jambudvipa.

analyzed: vistaram maṇḍalam yat ca yojanaiḥ tān nibodhata
translated: Listen to their extent and circumference in yojanas.

original: yojanānāṃ sahasrāṇi śataṃ dvīpasya vistaraḥ /🔽nānājanapadākīrṇaṃ puraiśca vividhaiḥ śubhaiḥ // / //
analyzed: yojanānām sahasrāṇi śatam dvīpasya vistaraḥ  nānā janapada ākīrṇam puraiḥ ca vividhaiḥ śubhaiḥ
translated: The extent of the continent is one hundred thousand yojanas.🔽It is crowded with various countries and beautiful cities.

analyzed: siddha cāraṇa saṃkīrṇam parvataiḥ upaśobhitam
translated: It is filled with Siddhas and Charanas and adorned with mountains.

analyzed: sarva dhātu pinaddhaiḥ taiḥ śilā jāla samudgataiḥ
translated: They are made of all minerals and rise up with masses of rock.

analyzed: parvata prabhavābhiḥ ca nadībhiḥ tu samantataḥ
translated: And all around with rivers flowing from the mountains.

analyzed: prāc āyatāḥ mahā pārśvāḥ ṣaṭ ime varṣaparvatāḥ
translated: These six great mountain ranges extend from east to west.

analyzed: avagāhya hi ubhayatas samudrau pūrva paścimau
translated: Having entered both the eastern and western oceans,

analyzed: hima prāyaḥ ca himavān hemakūṭaḥ ca hemavān
translated: The Himalayas are mostly snow, the Hemakūṭa is golden,

analyzed: sarvatas sumukhaḥ ca api niṣadhaḥ parvataḥ mahān
translated: The great Niṣadha mountain is good-faced on all sides.

analyzed: cāturvarṇyaḥ tu sauvarṇaḥ meruḥ ca ulba mayaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: Meru is said to be made of gold, and the four varnas are remembered as being made of clay.

analyzed: caturviṃśat sahasrāṇi vistīrṇaḥ sa caturdiśam
translated: It is twenty-four thousand yojanas in extent in the four directions,

analyzed: vṛtta ākṛti pramāṇaḥ ca catur asraḥ samāhitaḥ
translated: Round in shape and size, and evenly square.

analyzed: nānā varṇaiḥ samaḥ pārśvaiḥ prajāpati guṇa anvitaḥ
translated: With sides of various colors, endowed with the qualities of Prajāpati,

analyzed: nābhī bandhana sambhūtaḥ brahmaṇaḥ vyakta janmanaḥ
translated: Arisen from the navel-bond of Brahmā, born from the unmanifest,

original: pūrvataḥ śvetavarṇastu brāhmaṇyaṃ tasya tena vai // / //🔽pītaśca dakṣiṇenāsau tena vaiśyatvamiṣyeta /
analyzed: pūrvatas śveta varṇaḥ tu brāhmaṇyam tasya tena vai  pītaḥ ca dakṣiṇena asau tena vaiśya tvam iṣyeta
translated: To the east it is white in color, by that it has the nature of a brahmin,🔽And to the south it is yellow, by that it is considered to have the nature of a vaiśya,

analyzed: ca eva paścimena samanvitaḥ
translated: And to the west it is endowed with the color of a bee's wing,

analyzed: tena asya śūdra tā siddhā meroḥ nāma artha karmataḥ
translated: By that, the śūdra nature of Meru is established, according to the meaning of its name.

analyzed: pārśvam uttaratas tasya rakta varṇam svabhāvataḥ
translated: To the north of it, the side is naturally red in color,

original: tenāsya kṣatrabhāvaḥ syād iti varṇāḥ prakīrtitāḥ // / //🔽nīlaśca vaiḍūryamayaḥ śvetaḥ pīto hiraṇmayaḥ /
analyzed: tena asya kṣatra bhāvaḥ syāt iti varṇāḥ prakīrtitāḥ  nīlaḥ ca vaiḍūrya mayaḥ śvetaḥ pītaḥ hiraṇmayaḥ
translated: Therefore, his caste would be Kshatriya, thus the castes are proclaimed.🔽The blue one is made of lapis lazuli, the white one is golden, and the yellow one is made of gold.

analyzed: mayūra barha varṇaḥ ca śātakaumbhaḥ sa śṛṅgavān
translated: The one with the color of a peacock's tail is made of silver, and it has peaks.

analyzed: ete parvata rājānaḥ siddha cāraṇa sevitāḥ
translated: These are the kings of mountains, frequented by Siddhas and Charanas.

analyzed: teṣām antara viṣkambhaḥ nava sāhasram ucyate
translated: The distance between them is said to be nine thousand (leagues).

analyzed: madhye tu ilāvṛtam nāma mahāmeroḥ samantataḥ
translated: In the middle, there is the region called Ilavrita, all around the great Meru.

analyzed: caturviṃśat sahasrāṇi vistīrṇaḥ yojanaiḥ samaḥ
translated: It is twenty-four thousand (leagues) in extent, and equal in size.

original: madhye tasya mahāmerur vidhūma iva pāvakaḥ /
analyzed: madhye tasya mahā meruḥ vidhūmaḥ iva pāvakaḥ
translated: In the middle of it is the great Meru, like a fire without smoke.

analyzed: vedyardham dakṣiṇam meroḥ uttarārdham tathā uttaram
translated: The southern half of Meru is known as Videha, and the northern half is known as Uttara.

original: varṣāṇi yāni saptātra teṣāṃ vai varṣaparvatāḥ /
analyzed: varṣāṇi yāni sapta atra teṣām vai varṣaparvatāḥ
translated: The seven varshas here have their own mountain ranges.

analyzed: dve dve sahasre vistīrṇāḥ yojanaiḥ dakṣiṇa uttaram
translated: Each is two thousand (leagues) in extent from south to north.

analyzed: jambūdvīpasya vistāraḥ teṣām āyāmaḥ ucyate
translated: The extent of Jambudvipa is said to be their length.

original: nīlaśca niṣadhaścaiva teṣāṃ hīnāśca ye pare // / //
analyzed: nīlaḥ ca niṣadhaḥ ca eva teṣām hīnāḥ ca ye pare
translated: Nila and Nishadha, and those that are inferior to them,

analyzed: śvetaḥ ca hemakūṭaḥ ca himavān śṛṅgavān ca yaḥ
translated: Shveta, Hemakoota, and Himavat with its peaks,

analyzed: jambūdvīpa pramāṇeṇa ṛṣabhaḥ parikīrtyate
translated: Rishabha is said to be equal to Jambudvipa in size.

analyzed: tasmāt dvādaśa bhāgena hemakūṭaḥ u pi hīyate
translated: From that, Hemakūṭa is also diminished by one-twelfth.

analyzed: himavān viṃśa bhāgena tasmāt eva prahīyate
translated: Himālaya is diminished by twenty parts from that itself.

analyzed: aṣṭāśīti sahasrāṇi hemakūṭaḥ mahā giriḥ
translated: The great mountain Hemakūṭa is eighty-eight thousand (yojanas high).

analyzed: aśītiḥ himavān śailaḥ āyataḥ pūrva paścime
translated: The Himālaya mountain is eighty thousand (yojanas high) from east to west.

analyzed: dvīpasya maṇḍalībhāvāt dhrāsa vṛddhī prakīrtite
translated: Due to the circular shape of the continent, the decrease and increase are proclaimed.

analyzed: varṣāṇām parvatānām ca yathā bhedam tathā uttaram
translated: The divisions of the years and mountains are as stated above.

original: teṣāṃ madhye janapadās tāni varṣāṇi sapta vai // / //
analyzed: teṣām madhye janapadāḥ tāni varṣāṇi sapta vai
translated: In the middle of them are the countries, those seven years.

analyzed: prapāta viṣamaiḥ taiḥ tu parvataiḥ āvṛtāni tu
translated: They are surrounded by those mountains with precipices and uneven terrain.

analyzed: sapta tāni nadī bhedaiḥ agamyāni parasparam
translated: Those seven are not accessible to each other due to the divisions of the rivers.

analyzed: vasanti teṣu sattvāni nānā jātīni sarvaśas
translated: Beings of various species live in them everywhere.

original: imaṃ haimavataṃ varṣaṃ bhārataṃ nāma viśrutam // / //
analyzed: imam haimavatam varṣam bhāratam nāma viśrutam
translated: This Himalayan year is known as Bhārata.

original: hemakūṭaṃ paraṃ tasmān nāmnā kimpuruṣaṃ smṛtam /
analyzed: hemakūṭam param tasmāt nāmnā kimpuruṣam smṛtam
translated: Beyond that is Hemakūṭa, known by the name of Kiṃpuruṣa.

analyzed: hemakūṭāt ca niṣadham harivarṣam tat ucyate
translated: And beyond Hemakūṭa is Niṣadha, called Harivarṣa.

analyzed: harivarṣāt param ca api meroḥ tu tat ilāvṛtam
translated: Beyond Harivarṣa is Meru's Ilāvṛta.

analyzed: ilāvṛtāt param nīlam ramyakam nāma viśrutam
translated: Beyond Ilāvṛta is the Nīla mountain, known as Ramyaka.

analyzed: ramyakāt aparam śvetam viśrutam tat hiraṇyakam
translated: Beyond Ramyaka is the white mountain, known as Hiraṇyaka.

original: hiraṇyakātparaṃ caiva śṛṅgaśākaṃkuraṃ smṛtam // / //🔽dhanuḥsaṃsthe tu vijñeye devarṣe dakṣiṇottare /
analyzed: hiraṇyakāt param ca eva śṛṅgaśākaṃkuram smṛtam  dhanuḥ saṃsthe tu vijñeye deva ṛṣe dakṣiṇa uttare
translated: Beyond Hiraṇyaka is remembered the Śṛṅgaśākaka mountain.

original: dīrghāṇi tasya catvāri madhyamaṃ tadilāvṛtam // / //🔽pūrvato niṣadhasyedaṃ vedyardhaṃ dakṣiṇaṃ smṛtam /
analyzed: dīrghāṇi tasya catvāri madhyamam tat ilāvṛtam  pūrvatas niṣadhasya idam vedyardham dakṣiṇam smṛtam
translated: O celestial sage, the four long mountains should be known to be on the south and north of the Dhanus (i.e. Sagittarius) and Aquarius signs.🔽The middle one is the Ilāvṛta Varṣa.🔽This half of the sacrificial surface to the east of Niṣadha is known as the southern one.

original: paraṃ tvilāvṛtaṃ paścād vedyardhaṃ tu taduttaram // / //
analyzed: param tu ilāvṛtam paścāt vedyardham tu tat uttaram
translated: But the Ilāvṛta Varṣa is beyond it, to the west, and that is the northern half of the sacrificial surface.

analyzed: tayoḥ madhye tu vijñeyaḥ meruḥ yatra tu ilāvṛtam
translated: Between them, Meru should be known, where the Ilāvṛta Varṣa is.

analyzed: dakṣiṇena tu nīlasya niṣadhasya uttareṇa tu
translated: To the south of Nīla and to the north of Niṣadha,

analyzed: udak āyataḥ mahā śailaḥ mālyavān nāma parvataḥ
translated: is the great mountain Mālyavat, extending to the north.

analyzed: dvātriṃśatā sahasreṇa pratīcyām sāgara anugaḥ
translated: It extends to the west for thirty-two thousand (leagues) along the ocean.

analyzed: mālyavān vai sahasraikaḥ ā nīla niṣadha āyataḥ
translated: Mālyavat extends for one thousand (leagues) from Nīla to Niṣadha.

analyzed: dvātriṃśat tu evam api uktaḥ parvataḥ gandhamādanaḥ
translated: Thus, the mountain Gandhamādana is said to be thirty-two (thousand leagues).

analyzed: parimaṇḍalayoḥ madhye meruḥ kanakaparvataḥ
translated: Between the two circles is Meru, the golden mountain.

analyzed: cāturvarṇya samaḥ varṇaiḥ catur asraḥ samucchritaḥ
translated: The four sides are equal to the four castes, and it is lofty.

original: nānāvarṇaḥ sa pārśveṣu pūrvānte śveta ucyate /
analyzed: nānā varṇaḥ sa pārśveṣu pūrva ante śvetaḥ ucyate
translated: On its sides are various colors. The eastern end is said to be white.

original: pītaṃ tu dakṣiṇaṃ tasya bhṛṅgipattranibhaṃ param /
analyzed: pītam tu dakṣiṇam tasya bhṛṅgi pattra nibham param
translated: The southern side is yellow, the next is like the wing of a bee.

analyzed: uttaram tasya raktam vai iti varṇa samanvitaḥ  meruḥ tu śuśubhe divyaḥ rāja vat sa tu veṣṭitaḥ
translated: The northern side is red, thus it is endowed with colors.🔽Meru, indeed, shines like a divine king, surrounded by the directions.

analyzed: āditya taruṇa ābhāsaḥ vidhūmaḥ iva pāvakaḥ
translated: Shining like the rising sun, like a fire without smoke.

analyzed: yojanānām sahasrāṇi
translated: It is eighty-four thousand yojanas high.

analyzed: praviṣṭaḥ ṣoḍaśa adhastāt aṣṭāviṃśati vistṛtaḥ
translated: Sixteen below, twenty-eight wide.

analyzed: vistarāt dviguṇaḥ ca asya parīṇāhaḥ samantataḥ
translated: Its circumference is twice as wide as its breadth on all sides.

analyzed: sa parvataḥ mahā divyaḥ divya oṣadhi samanvitaḥ
translated: That mountain is greatly divine, endowed with divine herbs.

analyzed: bhuvanaiḥ āvṛtaḥ sarvaiḥ jātarūpa pariṣkṛtaiḥ
translated: It is surrounded by all the worlds, adorned with gold.

analyzed: tatra deva gaṇāḥ ca eva gandharva asura rākṣasāḥ
translated: There the hosts of gods, gandharvas, asuras, and rakshasas,

analyzed: śailarāje pramodante sarvatas psarasām gaṇaiḥ
translated: Rejoice in the king of mountains, with the hosts of celestial nymphs on all sides.

analyzed: sa tu meruḥ parivṛtaḥ bhuvanaiḥ bhūta bhāvanaiḥ
translated: That Meru is surrounded by the worlds that sustain beings,

analyzed: yasya ime caturaḥ deśāḥ nānā pārśveṣu saṃsthitāḥ
translated: Whose four countries are situated on different sides,

original: bhadrāśvaṃ bhārataṃ caiva ketumālaṃ ca paścime /
analyzed: bhadrāśvam bhāratam ca eva ketumālam ca paścime
translated: Bhadraśva, Bhārata, Ketumāla in the west,

analyzed: uttarāḥ ca eva kuravaḥ kṛta puṇya pratiśrayāḥ
translated: And the northern Kurus, the abode of those who have performed meritorious deeds,

analyzed: viṣkambha parvatāḥ tadvat mandaraḥ gandhamādanaḥ
translated: The Viṣkaṃbha mountains, Mandara, Gandhamādana,

analyzed: vipulaḥ ca supārśvaḥ ca sarva ratna vibhūṣitāḥ
translated: And Vipula and Supārśva, all adorned with jewels,

analyzed: aruṇodam mānasam ca sita udam bhadra saṃjñitam
translated: The red-watered Mānasa, the white-watered one called Bhadra,

original: teṣāmupari catvāri sarāṃsi ca vanāni ca // / //
analyzed: teṣām upari catvāri sarāṃsi ca vanāni ca
translated: Above them are four lakes and forests,

analyzed: tathā bhadra kadambaḥ tu parvate gandhamādane
translated: Similarly, the Bhadraka grove is on Mount Gandhamādana,

analyzed: jambu vṛkṣaḥ tathā aśvatthaḥ vipule vaṭaḥ param
translated: The rose-apple tree, the holy fig tree, in Vipula, and the banyan tree beyond,

analyzed: gandhamādana pārśve tu paścime maragaṇḍikaḥ
translated: On the western side of Gandhamādana is Amaragandhika,

analyzed: dvātriṃśat ca sahasrāṇi yojanaiḥ sarvatas samaḥ
translated: Thirty-two thousand yojanas in circumference,

analyzed: tatra te śubha karmāṇaḥ ketumālāḥ pariśrutāḥ
translated: There the doers of good deeds are known as Ketumāla,

analyzed: tatra kāla analāḥ sarve mahāsattvāḥ mahā balāḥ
translated: There all the Kālakalas are of great courage and great strength,

analyzed: striyaḥ ca utpala varṇa ābhāḥ sundaryaḥ priya darśanāḥ
translated: And the women are of the color of lotuses, beautiful and pleasing to behold,

analyzed: tatra divyaḥ mahā vṛkṣaḥ panasaḥ pattra bhāsuraḥ
translated: There is a great divine tree, a jackfruit tree, shining with leaves.

analyzed: tasya pītvā phala rasam saṃjīvanti samā ayutam
translated: Having drunk the juice of its fruit, they revive together.

original: tasya mālyavataḥ pārśve pūrve pūrvā tu gaṇḍikā /
analyzed: tasya mālyavataḥ pārśve pūrve pūrvā tu gaṇḍikā
translated: On the eastern side of that Malaya, the eastern Gandhika,

analyzed: dvātriṃśat ca sahasrāṇi tatra api śatam ucyate
translated: there are thirty-two thousand, and there also a hundred is said.

analyzed: bhadrāśvaḥ tatra vijñeyaḥ nityam mudita mānasaḥ
translated: There, Bhadrashva should be known, always cheerful in mind.

analyzed: bhadramālavanam tatra kāla āmraḥ ca mahā drumaḥ
translated: There is the Bhadravala forest, and the great tree Kalakuta.

original: tatra te puruṣāḥ śvetā mahāsattvā mahābalāḥ /
analyzed: tatra te puruṣāḥ śvetāḥ mahāsattvāḥ mahā balāḥ
translated: There, those men are white, of great spirit, and of great strength.

analyzed: striyaḥ kumuda varṇa ābhāḥ sundaryaḥ priya darśanāḥ
translated: The women are beautiful, lovely to behold, with the complexion of lilies.

analyzed: candra prabhāḥ candra varṇāḥ pūrṇa candra nibha ānanāḥ
translated: They have the luster of the moon, the color of the moon, faces like the full moon.

analyzed: candra śītala gātrāḥ ca striyaḥ hi utpala gandhikāḥ
translated: Their bodies are cool like the moon, and the women have the fragrance of lotuses.

analyzed: daśa varṣa sahasrāṇi āyuḥ teṣām anāmayam
translated: Their lifespan is ten thousand years, free from disease.

original: kālāmrasya rasaṃ pītvā te sarve sthirayauvanāḥ // / //
analyzed: kāla āmrasya rasam pītvā te sarve sthira yauvanāḥ
translated: Having drunk the juice of the Kalakuta, they all have stable youth.

analyzed: sūtaḥ uvāca
translated: The Suta said:

analyzed: iti uktavān ṛṣīn brahmā varṣāṇi ca nisargataḥ
translated: Thus spoke Brahma to the sages about the years and their natural course.

analyzed: pūrvam mama anugraha kṛt bhūyas kim varṇayāmi vaḥ
translated: Having shown me favor before, what else shall I describe to you?

analyzed: etat śrutvā vacaḥ te tu ṛṣayaḥ saṃśita vratāḥ
translated: Hearing these words, the sages of rigid vows,

analyzed: jāta kautūhalāḥ sarve pratyūcuḥ te mudā anvitāḥ
translated: all filled with curiosity, replied with joy.

analyzed: ṛṣayaḥ ūcuḥ
translated: The sages said:

original: pūrvāparau samākhyātau yau deśau tau tvayā mune /
analyzed: pūrva aparau samākhyātau yau deśau tau tvayā mune
translated: O sage, you have described the eastern and western countries,

original: uttarāṇāṃ ca varṣāṇāṃ parvatānāṃ ca sarvaśaḥ // / //
analyzed: uttarāṇām ca varṣāṇām parvatānām ca sarvaśas
translated: and all the northern countries and mountains.

original: ākhyāhi no yathātathyaṃ ye ca parvatavāsinaḥ /
analyzed: ākhyāhi naḥ yathātathyam ye ca parvata vāsinaḥ
translated: Tell us accurately who live in the mountains.

analyzed: evam uktaḥ tu ṛṣibhiḥ tebhyaḥ tu ākhyātavān punar
translated: Thus asked by the sages, he again described to them.

analyzed: sūtaḥ uvāca
translated: Suta said:

analyzed: śṛṇudhvam yāni varṣāṇi pūrva uktāni ca vai mayā
translated: Listen to the countries mentioned by me earlier,

analyzed: dakṣiṇena tu nīlasya niṣadhasya uttareṇa tu
translated: to the south of Nila and north of Nishadha,

original: varṣaṃ ramaṇakaṃ nāma jāyante yatra vai prajāḥ /
analyzed: varṣam ramaṇakam nāma jāyante yatra vai prajāḥ
translated: there is a country named Ramana, where people are born.

analyzed: rati pradhānāḥ vimalāḥ jāyante yatra mānavāḥ
translated: People born there are mainly devoted to pleasure and are pure.

analyzed: śukla abhijana sampannāḥ sarve te priya darśanāḥ
translated: All of them are born in a pure family and are handsome.

original: tatrāpi ca mahāvṛkṣo nyagrodho rohiṇo mahān /
analyzed: tatra api ca mahā vṛkṣaḥ nyagrodhaḥ rohiṇaḥ mahān
translated: There is also a great tree, a large banyan tree,

original: tasyāpi te phalarasaṃ pibanto vartayanti hi // / //
analyzed: tasya api te phala rasam pibantaḥ vartayanti hi
translated: drinking the juice of its fruits, they live.

analyzed: daśa varṣa sahasrāṇi daśa varṣa śatāni ca
translated: For ten thousand and ten hundred years,

original: jīvanti te mahābhāgāḥ sadā hṛṣṭā narottamāḥ // / //
analyzed: jīvanti te mahābhāgāḥ sadā hṛṣṭāḥ nara uttamāḥ
translated: Those greatly fortunate and best of men always live happily there.

original: uttareṇa tu śvetasya pārśve śṛṅgasya dakṣiṇe /
analyzed: uttareṇa tu śvetasya pārśve śṛṅgasya dakṣiṇe
translated: To the north of Shveta's peak and to the south of the peak,

original: varṣaṃ hiraṇvataṃ nāma yatra hairaṇvatī nadī // / //
analyzed: varṣam hiraṇvatam nāma yatra hairaṇvatī nadī
translated: There is a land named Hiranyavat, where the river Hiranyavati flows.

analyzed: mahā balāḥ mahāsattvāḥ nityam mudita mānasāḥ
translated: They are greatly powerful, greatly courageous, and always cheerful in mind.

original: śuklābhijanasampannāḥ sarve ca priyadarśanāḥ // / //🔽ekādaśa sahasrāṇi varṣāṇāṃ te narottamāḥ /
analyzed: śukla abhijana sampannāḥ sarve ca priya darśanāḥ  ekādaśa sahasrāṇi varṣāṇām te nara uttamāḥ
translated: All of them are born in the Shudra caste and are handsome to behold.🔽Those best of men live for eleven thousand years,

original: āyuṣpramāṇaṃ jīvanti śatāni daśa pañca ca // / //
analyzed: āyuṣpramāṇam jīvanti śatāni daśa pañca ca
translated: For one hundred and fifty years.

analyzed: tasmin varṣe mahā vṛkṣaḥ lakucaḥ pattra saṃśrayaḥ
translated: In that land, there is a large tree named Lakucha, which provides shelter for leaves.

original: tasya pītvā phalarasaṃ tatra jīvanti mānavāḥ // / //
analyzed: tasya pītvā phala rasam tatra jīvanti mānavāḥ

analyzed: abhigacchanti tāḥ ca anyāḥ nadāḥ nadyaḥ sarāṃsi ca
translated: And other rivers, streams, and lakes flow into them,

analyzed: bahu udaka parisrāvāḥ yatas varṣati vāsavaḥ
translated: from where Indra rains down, with abundant water flowing.

original: tāsāṃ tu nāmadheyāni parimāṇaṃ tathaiva ca /
analyzed: tāsām tu nāmadheyāni parimāṇam tathā eva ca
translated: The names and extent of those rivers,

analyzed: na śakyam parisaṃkhyātum puṇyāḥ tāḥ sarit uttamāḥ
translated: those auspicious and excellent rivers, cannot be fully enumerated.

original: tāḥ pibanti sadā hṛṣṭā nadīrjanapadāstu te /
analyzed: tāḥ pibanti sadā hṛṣṭāḥ nadīḥ janapadāḥ tu te
translated: The people of those countries always drink those rivers with joy,

analyzed: ete śānta bhayāḥ proktāḥ pramodāḥ ye ca vai śivāḥ
translated: those known as Shantbhaya, Pramoda, Shiva,

analyzed: ānandāḥ ca sukhāḥ ca eva kṣemakāḥ ca navaiḥ saha
translated: Ananda, Sukha, Kshemaka, and Nava.

analyzed: varṇa āśrama ācāra yutāḥ deśāḥ te sapta viśrutāḥ
translated: Those seven countries are famous for their adherence to the duties of caste and stage of life.

analyzed: ārogyāḥ balinaḥ ca eva sarve maraṇa varjitāḥ
translated: They are all healthy, strong, and free from death,

analyzed: avasarpiṇī na teṣu asti tathā eva utsarpiṇī punar
translated: there is no decrease or increase there.

analyzed: na tatra asti yuga avasthā catur yuga kṛtā kvacid
translated: There is no division of the four yugas there,

analyzed: tretā yuga samaḥ kālaḥ tathā tatra pravartate
translated: the time there proceeds as in the Treta Yuga.

analyzed: śākadvīpa ādiṣu jñeyam pañcasu eteṣu sarvaśas
translated: In these five islands beginning with Śākadvīpa, it should be known that

original: deśasya tu vicāreṇa kālaḥ svābhāvikaḥ smṛtaḥ // / //
analyzed: deśasya tu vicāreṇa kālaḥ svābhāvikaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: Time is considered natural due to the consideration of the country.

original: na teṣu saṃkaraḥ kaścid varṇāśramakṛtaḥ kvacit /
analyzed: na teṣu saṃkaraḥ kaścid varṇa āśrama kṛtaḥ kvacid
translated: There is no mixture of castes or stages of life anywhere in them.

analyzed: dharmasya ca avyabhīcārāt ekānta sukhinaḥ prajāḥ
translated: And due to the non-deviation of Dharma, the people are absolutely happy.

original: na teṣu māyā lobho vā īrṣyāsūyā bhayaṃ kutaḥ /
analyzed: na teṣu māyā lobhaḥ vā īrṣyā asūyā bhayam kutas
translated: There is no illusion or greed, envy, malice or fear in them.

original: viparyayo na teṣvasti tadvai svābhāvikaṃ smṛtam // / //
analyzed: viparyayaḥ na teṣu asti tat vai svābhāvikam smṛtam

analyzed: svadharmeṇa ca dharma jñāḥ te rakṣanti parasparam
translated: And the people, knowing Dharma, protect each other by their own Dharma.

analyzed: parimaṇḍalaḥ tu su mahān dvīpaḥ vai kuśa saṃjñakaḥ
translated: The island named Kuśa is very large and circular.

analyzed: nadī jalaiḥ parivṛtaḥ parvataḥ ca abhra saṃnibhaiḥ
translated: It is surrounded by river waters and mountains resembling clouds.

analyzed: sarva dhātu vicitraiḥ ca maṇi vidruma bhūṣitaiḥ
translated: And by various minerals, adorned with gems and corals,

analyzed: anyaiḥ ca ramyaiḥ janapadaiḥ tathā  vṛkṣaiḥ puṣpa phala upetaiḥ sarvatas dhana dhānyavān
translated: And by various beautiful countries,🔽And by trees endowed with flowers and fruits, it is prosperous with wealth and grain everywhere.

analyzed: nityam puṣpa phala upetaḥ sarva ratna samāvṛtaḥ
translated: It is always endowed with flowers and fruits, and covered with all jewels.

analyzed: āvṛtaḥ paśubhiḥ sarvaiḥ grāmya āraṇyaiḥ ca sarvaśas
translated: He is surrounded by all the domestic and wild animals.

analyzed: ānupūrvyāt samāsena kuśadvīpam nibodhata
translated: Understand the Kusha Dvipa in brief in due order.

original: atha tṛtīyaṃ vakṣyāmi kuśadvīpaṃ ca kṛtsnaśaḥ /
analyzed: atha tṛtīyam vakṣyāmi kuśadvīpam ca kṛtsnaśas
translated: Now I shall describe the third, the entire Kusha Dvipa.

analyzed: kuśadvīpena kṣīrodaḥ sarvatas parivāritaḥ
translated: The ocean of milk is surrounded on all sides by the Kusha Dvipa.

analyzed: śākadvīpasya vistārāt dviguṇena samanvitaḥ
translated: It is endowed with a width twice that of the Shaka Dvipa.

analyzed: tatra api parvatāḥ sapta vijñeyāḥ ratna yonayaḥ
translated: There also, the mountains should be known as having jewels as their source.

original: ratnākarāstathā nadyas teṣāṃ nāmāni me śṛṇu /
analyzed: ratna ākarāḥ tathā nadyaḥ teṣām nāmāni me śṛṇu
translated: Listen to the names of the jewel mines and rivers.

original: dvināmānaśca te sarve śākadvīpe yathā tathā // / //
analyzed: dvi nāmānaḥ ca te sarve śākadvīpe yathā tathā
translated: All of them have two names, just as in the Shaka Dvipa.

analyzed: prathamaḥ sūrya saṃkāśaḥ kumudaḥ nāma parvataḥ
translated: The first mountain is like the sun and is named Kumuda.

original: vidrumoccaya ityuktaḥ sa eva ca mahīdharaḥ // / //
analyzed: vidruma uccayaḥ iti uktaḥ saḥ eva ca mahīdharaḥ
translated: It is also called Vidrumaucchhaya, the mountain.

analyzed: sarva dhātu mayaiḥ śṛṅgaiḥ śilā jāla samanvitaiḥ
translated: With peaks made of all minerals, covered with nets of rocks,

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ parvataḥ tatra unnataḥ nāma viśrutaḥ
translated: The second mountain there is known as Unnata.

original: hemaparvata ityuktaḥ sa eva ca mahīdharaḥ /
analyzed: hemaparvataḥ iti uktaḥ saḥ eva ca mahīdharaḥ
translated: It is also called Hemaparvata, the mountain.

analyzed: haritāla mayaiḥ śṛṅgaiḥ dvīpam āvṛtya sarvaśas
translated: With peaks made of yellow orpiment, covering the island on all sides,

analyzed: balāhakaḥ tṛtīyaḥ tu jāti añjana mayaḥ giriḥ
translated: The third mountain is Valahaka, composed of collyrium.

original: dyutimānnāmataḥ proktaḥ sa eva ca mahīdharaḥ // / //
analyzed: dyutimān nāmataḥ proktaḥ saḥ eva ca mahīdharaḥ
translated: It is known as Dyutimat, that very mountain.

analyzed: caturthaḥ parvataḥ droṇaḥ yatra auṣadhyaḥ mahā girau
translated: The fourth mountain is Drona, where there are herbs on the great mountain.

analyzed: viśalya karaṇī ca eva mṛtasaṃjīvanī tathā
translated: There is Vishalya Karani (wound healer) and Mrita Sanjivani (reviver of the dead).

analyzed: puṣpavān nāma sa eva uktaḥ parvataḥ su mahā citaḥ
translated: That very mountain is called Pushpavan, of great height.

analyzed: kaṅkaḥ tu pañcamaḥ teṣām parvataḥ nāma sāravān
translated: Kank is the fifth of those mountains, named Saravata.

original: kuśeśaya iti proktaḥ punaḥ sa pṛthivīdharaḥ /
analyzed: kuśeśayaḥ iti proktaḥ punar sa pṛthivīdharaḥ
translated: That upholder of the earth is again called Kushieshaya.

analyzed: divya puṣpa phala upetaḥ
translated: Endowed with divine flowers and fruits, and possessing divine birds.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭhaḥ tu parvataḥ tatra mahiṣaḥ megha saṃnibhaḥ
translated: The sixth mountain there is Mahiṣa, resembling a cloud.

original: sa eva tu punaḥ prokto harirityabhiviśrutaḥ // / //
analyzed: saḥ eva tu punar proktaḥ hariḥ iti abhiviśrutaḥ
translated: He is again called Hari, renowned by that name.

analyzed: tasmin saḥ agniḥ nivasati mahiṣaḥ nāma yaḥ u psu jaḥ
translated: In him dwells that fire named Mahiṣa, born from the waters.

analyzed: saptamaḥ parvataḥ tatra kakudmān sa hi bhāṣate  mandaraḥ sa eva vijñeyaḥ sarva dhātu mayaḥ śubhaḥ
translated: The seventh mountain there is Kakudmat, who speaks.🔽He should be known as Mandara, auspicious, composed of all minerals.

analyzed: mandaḥ iti eṣa yaḥ dhātuḥ apām arthe prakāśakaḥ
translated: This element called Mand is the revealer of the purpose of the waters.

analyzed: apām vidāraṇāt ca eva mandaraḥ sa nigadyate

analyzed: tatra ratnāni anekāni svayam rakṣati vāsavaḥ

analyzed: prajāpatim upādāya prajābhyaḥ vidadhat svayam

analyzed: teṣām antara viṣkambhaḥ dviguṇaḥ samudāhṛtaḥ
translated: The distance between them is said to be double.

analyzed: iti ete parvatāḥ sapta kuśadvīpe prabhāṣitāḥ
translated: Thus these seven mountains are mentioned in the Kusha Dvipa.

original: teṣāṃ varṣāṇi vakṣyāmi saptaiva tu vibhāgaśaḥ // / //
analyzed: teṣām varṣāṇi vakṣyāmi sapta eva tu vibhāgaśaḥ

analyzed: kumudasya smṛtaḥ śvetaḥ unnataḥ ca iva sa smṛtaḥ

analyzed: unnatasya tu vijñeyam varṣam lohita saṃjñakam

analyzed: veṇumaṇḍalakam ca eva tathā eva parikīrtitam

analyzed: balāhakasya jīmūtaḥ svairatha ākāram iti api

analyzed: kaṅkasya api kakud nāma dhṛtimat ca eva tat smṛtam
translated: Of Kankaka, it is named Kakun and also remembered as Dhritimat.

analyzed: mahiṣam mahiṣasya api punar ca api prabhākaram
translated: Of Mahisha, it is also named Mahiisha and again Prabhakara.

analyzed: kakudminaḥ tu tat varṣam kapilam nāma viśrutam
translated: Of Kakudmin, that varsha is known as Kapila.

analyzed: etāni api viśiṣṭāni sapta sapta pṛthak pṛthak

analyzed: varṣāṇi parvatāḥ ca eva nadīḥ teṣu nibodhata
translated: The mountains and rivers in them should be understood.

analyzed: dvi nāmavatyaḥ tāḥ sarvāḥ sarvāḥ puṇya jalāḥ smṛtāḥ
translated: All of them have two names, and all of them are said to have sacred waters.

original: dhūtapāpā nadī nāma yoniścaiva punaḥ smṛtā /
analyzed: dhūtapāpā nadī nāma yoniḥ ca eva punar smṛtā

analyzed: sītā dvitīyā vijñeyā sā ca eva hi niśā smṛtā
translated: The second one should be known as Sītā, and that is also remembered as Niśā.

analyzed: caturthī hlādinī iti uktā candrabhā iti ca smṛtā

analyzed: puṇḍrā ṣaṣṭhī tu vijñeyā punar ca eva vibhāvarī

analyzed: mahatī saptamī proktā punar ca eṣā dhṛtiḥ smṛtā

analyzed: anyāḥ tābhyaḥ saṃjātāḥ sahasraśas
translated: Others have also arisen from them, in hundreds and thousands.

original: abhigacchanti tā nadyo yato varṣati vāsavaḥ /
analyzed: abhigacchanti tāḥ nadyaḥ yatas varṣati vāsavaḥ

analyzed: sarvatas su mahān dvīpaḥ candra vat pariveṣṭitaḥ
translated: and is encircled by the ocean of milk like the moon.

analyzed: vistārāt maṇḍalāt ca eva kṣīrodāt dviguṇaḥ mataḥ

analyzed: tatas param pravakṣyāmi krauñcadvīpam yathā tathā

analyzed: kuśadvīpasya vistārāt dviguṇaḥ tasya vistaraḥ

analyzed: ghṛta udakaḥ samudraḥ vai krauñca dvīpena saṃvṛtaḥ
translated: The ocean of ghee is surrounded by the Krauncha Dvīpa,

analyzed: cakranemi pramāṇena vṛtaḥ vṛttena sarvaśas

analyzed: tasmin dvīpe nagāḥ śreṣṭhāḥ devanaḥ giriḥ ucyate

analyzed: devanāt paratas ca api govindaḥ nāma parvataḥ
translated: Beyond Devana, there is a mountain named Govinda.

analyzed: govindāt paratas ca api krauñcaḥ tu prathamaḥ giriḥ
translated: Beyond Govinda, the first mountain is Krauncha.

analyzed: krauñcāt pare pāvanakaḥ pāvanāt andhakārakaḥ  andhakārāt pare ca api devāvṛt nāma parvataḥ
translated: Beyond Krauncha is Pāvana, beyond Pāvana is Andhakāraka.🔽Beyond Andhakāra is the mountain named Devāvarta.

analyzed: devāvṛtaḥ pareṇa api puṇḍarīkaḥ mahān giriḥ
translated: Beyond Devāvarta is the great mountain Puṇḍarīka.

analyzed: ete ratna mayāḥ sapta krauñcadvīpasya parvatāḥ
translated: These seven mountains are made of jewels in Kraunchadvipa.

analyzed: parasparasya dviguṇaḥ viṣkambhaḥ varṣaparvataḥ

analyzed: varṣāṇi tasya vakṣyāmi nāmataḥ tu nibodhata

analyzed: krauñcasya kuśalaḥ deśaḥ vāmanasya manonugaḥ

analyzed: manonugāt pare ca uṣṇāḥ saḥ ucyate
translated: Beyond Manonuga is Ushna, which is said to be the third.

analyzed: uṣṇāt pare pāvanakaḥ pāvanāt andhakārakaḥ
translated: Beyond Ushna is Pavanak, beyond Pavana is Andhakarika,

analyzed: andhakāraka deśāt tu munideśaḥ tathā paraḥ
translated: Beyond the country of Andhakarika is the country of Munis.

analyzed: munideśāt pare ca api procyate dundubhisvanaḥ
translated: Beyond the country of Munis is said to be Dundubhisvana,

analyzed: siddha cāraṇa saṃkīrṇaḥ gaura prāyaḥ śuciḥ janaḥ
translated: Filled with Siddhas and Charanas, the people are mostly fair and pure.

analyzed: śrutāḥ tatra eva nadyaḥ tu prativarṣam gatāḥ śubhāḥ
translated: The auspicious rivers flowing there are said to be seven, going to each country.

analyzed: gaurī kumudvatī ca eva saṃdhyā rātriḥ manojavā
translated: Gauri, Kumudvati, Sandhya, Night, Manojava,

original: khyātī ca puṇḍarīkā ca gaṅgā saptavidhā smṛtā // / //🔽tāsāṃ sahasraśaścānyā nadyaḥ pārśvasamīpagāḥ /
analyzed: khyātī ca puṇḍarīkā ca gaṅgā saptavidhā smṛtā  tāsām sahasraśas ca anyāḥ nadyaḥ pārśva samīpa gāḥ
translated: Khatika, and Pundarika - Ganga is said to be sevenfold.🔽There are thousands of other rivers flowing by their sides.

analyzed: abhigacchanti tāḥ nadyaḥ bahulāḥ ca bahu udakāḥ
translated: Those many rivers with abundant water go there.

analyzed: teṣām nisargaḥ deśānām ānupūrvyeṇa sarvaśas
translated: The creation of those countries, in due order, in every way,

analyzed: na śakyaḥ vistarāt vaktum api varṣa śataiḥ api
translated: The creation of those countries, in due order, cannot be described in detail even in hundreds of years.

original: sargo yaśca prajānāṃ tu saṃhāro yaśca teṣu vai /
analyzed: sargaḥ yaḥ ca prajānām tu saṃhāraḥ yaḥ ca teṣu vai
translated: The creation of the beings and their dissolution in them,

analyzed: atas ūrdhvam pravakṣyāmi śālmalasya nibodhata
translated: From here onwards I will describe the Shalmala. Listen...

analyzed: śālmalaḥ dviguṇaḥ dvīpaḥ krauñca dvīpasya vistarāt
translated: The Shalmala continent is twice the size of Krauncha Dvipa,

analyzed: parivārya samudram tu dadhimaṇḍa udakam sthitaḥ
translated: Surrounding the ocean of curd-water.

original: tatra puṇyā janapadāś cirācca mriyate janaḥ /
analyzed: tatra puṇyāḥ janapadāḥ cirāt ca mriyate janaḥ
translated: The people there are virtuous and die after a long time.

original: kuta eva tu durbhikṣaṃ kṣamātejoyutā hi te // / //
analyzed: kutas eva tu durbhikṣam kṣamā tejaḥ yutāḥ hi te
translated: How can there be famine? They are endowed with the power of forgiveness and energy.

analyzed: prathamaḥ sūrya saṃkāśaḥ sumanāḥ nāma parvataḥ
translated: The first mountain is like the sun, named Sumanaprabha.

analyzed: pītaḥ tu madhyamaḥ ca āsīt tatas kumbha mayaḥ giriḥ
translated: The middle one is yellow, then the mountain is made of pot-like stones.

analyzed: nāmnā sarvasukhaḥ nāma divya oṣadhi samanvitaḥ
translated: Named Sarvasukha, endowed with divine herbs.

analyzed: tṛtīyaḥ ca eva sauvarṇaḥ bhṛṅga pattra nibhaḥ giriḥ
translated: The third is golden, the mountain is like the wings of a bee.

original: sumahānrohito nāma divyo girivaro hi saḥ /
analyzed: su mahān rohitaḥ nāma divyaḥ giri varaḥ hi saḥ
translated: The great divine best mountain is named Rohita.

analyzed: sumanāḥ kuśalaḥ deśaḥ sukha udarkaḥ sukha udayaḥ
translated: The country Sumanakusha is auspicious, leading to happiness, and brings happiness.

analyzed: rohitaḥ yaḥ tṛtīyaḥ tu rohiṇaḥ nāma viśrutaḥ
translated: The third one, Rohita, is known as Rohini.

analyzed: tatra ratnāni anekāni svayam rakṣati vāsavaḥ
translated: There, Indra himself protects many jewels.

analyzed: prajāpatim upādāya prasannaḥ vidadhat svayam
translated: From the beginning of creation, he himself, being pleased, arranges (everything).

original: na tatra meghā varṣanti śītoṣṇaṃ ca na tadvidham // / //
analyzed: na tatra meghāḥ varṣanti śīta uṣṇam ca na tadvidham
translated: There, the clouds do not rain, and the cold and heat are not like that.

original: varṇāśramāṇāṃ vārttā vā triṣu dvīpeṣu vidyate /
analyzed: varṇa āśramāṇām vārttā vā triṣu dvīpeṣu vidyate
translated: The occupations of the varnas and ashramas exist in the three islands.

analyzed: bhojanam ṣaṣ rasam tatra teṣām svayam upasthitam
translated: There, the food is of six tastes, and it presents itself to them.

original: adhamottamaṃ na teṣvasti na lobho na parigrahaḥ /
analyzed: adhama uttamam na teṣu asti na lobhaḥ na parigrahaḥ
translated: There is no high or low, no greed, no possession.

analyzed: ārogya balavantaḥ ca ekānta sukhinaḥ narāḥ
translated: The men are healthy, strong, and completely happy.

analyzed: triṃśat varṣa sahasrāṇi mānasīm siddhim āsthitāḥ
translated: For thirty thousand years, they attain mental perfection.

analyzed: sukham āyuḥ ca rūpam ca dharma aiśvaryam tathā eva ca
translated: Happiness, lifespan, beauty, and mastery of dharma -

analyzed: śālmala anteṣu vijñeyam dvīpeṣu triṣu sarvatas
translated: In the three islands ending with Shalmali, it should be known everywhere.

analyzed: vyākhyātaḥ śālmala antānām dvīpānām tu vidhiḥ śubhaḥ
translated: The auspicious method of the islands ending with Shalmali has been explained.

analyzed: parimaṇḍalaḥ tu dvīpasya cakra vat pariveṣṭitaḥ

analyzed: surodena samudreṇa dviguṇena samanvitaḥ
translated: It is surrounded by the ocean of sweet water, which is twice as large as the continent.

analyzed: matsyapurāṇa

analyzed: sūtaḥ uvāca
translated: Suta said:

original: gomedakaṃ pravakṣyāmi ṣaṣṭhaṃ dvīpaṃ tapodhanāḥ /🔽surodakasamudrastu gomedena samāvṛtaḥ // / //
analyzed: gomedakam pravakṣyāmi ṣaṣṭham dvīpam tapodhanāḥ  surodaka samudraḥ tu gomedena samāvṛtaḥ
translated: O ascetics, I shall now describe the sixth island, named Gomedha.🔽The ocean of sweet water is surrounded by Gomedha, which is twice the size of the previous island.

analyzed: śālmalasya tu vistārāt dviguṇaḥ tasya vistaraḥ
translated: The size of Gomedha is twice that of the previous island.

original: tasmindvīpe tu vijñeyau parvatau dvau samāhitau // / //
analyzed: tasmin dvīpe tu vijñeyau parvatau dvau samāhitau
translated: In that island, two mountains should be known, situated together.

analyzed: prathamaḥ sumanāḥ nāma jāti añjana mayaḥ giriḥ
translated: The first is named Sumanas, a mountain of antimony.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ kumudaḥ nāma sarva oṣadhi samanvitaḥ
translated: The second is named Kumuda, full of all herbs.

analyzed: śātakaumbha mayaḥ śrīmān vijñeyaḥ su mahā citaḥ
translated: It should be known as very large and made of gold.

analyzed: samudra ikṣu rasa udena vṛtaḥ gomedakaḥ ca saḥ
translated: Gomedha is surrounded by the ocean of sugarcane juice, which is twice the size of the ocean of sweet water.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭhena tu samudreṇa surodāt dviguṇena ca
translated: By the sixth ocean, which is twice the size of the ocean of sweet water,

original: dhātakīkumudaścaiva havyaputrau suvistṛtau // / //🔽saumanaṃ prathamaṃ varṣaṃ dhātakīkhaṇḍamucyate /
analyzed: dhātakī kumudaḥ ca eva havya putrau su vistṛtau  saumanam prathamam varṣam dhātakīkhaṇḍam ucyate
translated: the two sons of Havya, named Dhataki and Kumuda, are very extensive.🔽The first country is called Sumanas, and the first part of the first is called Dhatakikhanda.

original: dhātakinaḥ smṛtaṃ tadvai prathamaṃ prathamasya tu // / //
analyzed: dhātakinaḥ smṛtam tat vai prathamam prathamasya tu
translated: It is remembered as belonging to the Dhatakins.

original: gomedaṃ yatsmṛtaṃ varṣaṃ nāmnā sarvasukhaṃ tu tat /
analyzed: gomedam yat smṛtam varṣam nāmnā sarvasukham tu tat
translated: That which is known as the Gomēda Varṣa is called Sarvasukha.

analyzed: kumudasya dvitīyasya dvitīyam kumudam tatas
translated: The second of Kumuda is called Kumuda.

original: etau dvau parvatau vṛttau śeṣau sarvasamucchritau /
analyzed: etau dvau parvatau vṛttau śeṣau sarva samucchritau
translated: These two mountains are circular, the rest are all elevated.

analyzed: pūrveṇa tasya dvīpasya sumanāḥ parvataḥ sthitaḥ
translated: To the east of that Dvīpa, there is a mountain named Sumanas.

analyzed: prāc paścima āyataiḥ pādaiḥ āsamudrāt iti sthitaḥ
translated: It is situated with its feet extending from east to west to the ocean.

analyzed: paśca ardhe kumudaḥ tasya evam eva sthitaḥ tu vai
translated: In the western part of it, there is another mountain named Kumuda, situated in the same way.

original: etaiḥ parvatapādaistu sa deśo vai dvidhākṛtaḥ /
analyzed: etaiḥ parvata pādaiḥ tu sa deśaḥ vai dvidhā kṛtaḥ
translated: By these mountain feet, that country is divided into two parts.

analyzed: dakṣiṇa ardham tu dvīpasya dhātakīkhaṇḍam ucyate
translated: The southern half of the Dvīpa is called Dhātakīkhaṇḍa.

analyzed: kumudam tu uttare tasya dvitīyam varṣam uttamam
translated: To the north of it, there is another excellent Varṣa called Kumuda.

analyzed: etau janapadau dvau tu gomedasya tu vistṛtau
translated: These two countries are extensive in Gomēda.

analyzed: atas param pravakṣyāmi saptamam dvīpam uttamam
translated: Beyond this, I shall describe the seventh excellent Dvīpa.

analyzed: samudra ikṣu rasam ca eva gomedāt dviguṇam hi saḥ
translated: The ocean of sugarcane juice is twice the size of Gomēda.

analyzed: āvṛtya tiṣṭhati dvīpaḥ puṣkaraḥ puṣkaraiḥ vṛtaḥ

analyzed: puṣkareṇa vṛtaḥ śrīmān citrasānu mahā giriḥ

analyzed: kūṭaiḥ citraiḥ maṇi mayaiḥ śilā jāla samudbhavaiḥ
translated: With wonderful peaks made of jewels, rising from the mountain range.

original: dvīpasyaiva tu pūrvārdhe citrasānuḥ sthito mahān // / //
analyzed: dvīpasya eva tu pūrva ardhe citrasānuḥ sthitaḥ mahān
translated: In the eastern part of the continent itself, there is a great mountain with colorful peaks.

analyzed: parimaṇḍala sahasrāṇi vistīrṇaḥ saptaviṃśatiḥ

translated: Rising up twenty-four thousand leagues, it is extremely powerful.🔽In the western part of the continent, there is a mountain called Manasa,

analyzed: sthitaḥ velā samīpe tu pūrva candraḥ iva uditaḥ
translated: situated near the shore, like a rising crescent moon.

analyzed: yojanānām sahasrāṇi sārdham pañcāśat ucchritaḥ
translated: It is fifty-one thousand leagues high.

analyzed: tasya putraḥ mahāvītaḥ paścima ardhasya rakṣitā
translated: Its son, Mahāvita, is the protector of the western part.

original: pūrvārdhe parvatasyāpi dvidhā deśastu sa smṛtaḥ /
analyzed: pūrva ardhe parvatasya api dvidhā deśaḥ tu sa smṛtaḥ
translated: The eastern part of the mountain is also known as the two regions.

analyzed: svādu udakena udadhinā puṣkaraḥ parivāritaḥ
translated: Puṣkara is surrounded by the ocean of sweet water.

analyzed: vistārāt maṇḍalāt ca eva gomedāt dviguṇena tu
translated: It is twice as large as Gomeda in both circumference and diameter.

analyzed: triṃśat varṣa sahasrāṇi teṣu jīvanti mānavāḥ
translated: Humans live there for thirty thousand years.

analyzed: viparyayaḥ na teṣu asti etat svābhāvikam smṛtam
translated: There is no change in them, this is known as their natural state.

analyzed: ārogyam sukha bāhulyam mānasīm siddhim āsthitāḥ
translated: They are free from disease, have abundant happiness, and have attained mental perfection.

original: sukhamāyuśca rūpaṃ ca triṣu dvīpeṣu sarvaśaḥ /
analyzed: sukham āyuḥ ca rūpam ca triṣu dvīpeṣu sarvaśas
translated: Happiness, longevity, and beauty are equal in all three continents.

original: adhamottamau na teṣvāstāṃ tulyāste vīryarūpataḥ // / //🔽na tatra vadhyavadhakau nerṣyāsūyā bhayaṃ tathā /
analyzed: adhama uttamau na teṣu āstām tulyāḥ te vīrya rūpataḥ  na tatra vadhya vadhakau na īrṣyā asūyā bhayam tathā
translated: There are no low or high castes there, they are equal in virility and beauty.🔽There is no killing or being killed there, no envy, malice, or fear,

original: na lobho na ca dambho vā na ca dveṣaḥ parigrahaḥ // / //
analyzed: na lobhaḥ na ca dambhaḥ vā na ca dveṣaḥ parigrahaḥ
translated: no greed, hypocrisy, hatred, or possessiveness.

original: satyānṛte na teṣvāstāṃ dharmādharmau tathaiva ca /🔽varṇāśramāṇāṃ vārttā ca pāśupālyaṃ vaṇikkṛṣiḥ // / //
analyzed: satya anṛte na teṣu āstām dharma adharmau tathā eva ca  varṇa āśramāṇām vārttā ca pāśupālyam
translated: There is no truth or falsehood there, nor any Dharma or Adharma.🔽There are no castes or stages of life, no cattle-rearing, trade, or agriculture.

original: trayīvidyā daṇḍanītiḥ śuśrūṣā daṇḍa eva ca /
analyzed: trayī vidyā daṇḍanītiḥ śuśrūṣā daṇḍaḥ eva ca
translated: There is no knowledge of the three Vedas, no political science, no service, and no punishment.

original: na tatra varṣaṃ nadyo vā śītoṣṇaṃ ca na vidyate // / //
analyzed: na tatra varṣam nadyaḥ vā śīta uṣṇam ca na vidyate
translated: There is no rain or rivers there, and no cold or heat.

analyzed: udbhidāni udakāni syuḥ giri prasravaṇāni ca
translated: There are only springs and mountain streams.

analyzed: tulya uttarakurūṇām tu kālaḥ tatra tu sarvadā
translated: The seasons there are always like those in Uttarakuru.

analyzed: sarvatas sukha kālaḥ sau jarā kleśa vivarjitaḥ
translated: Everywhere it is a pleasant time, free from old age and suffering.

original: sargastu dhātakīkhaṇḍe mahāvīte tathaiva ca // / //🔽evaṃ dvīpāḥ samudraistu sapta saptabhirāvṛtāḥ /
analyzed: sargaḥ tu dhātakīkhaṇḍe mahāvīte tathā eva ca  evam dvīpāḥ samudraiḥ tu sapta saptabhiḥ āvṛtāḥ
translated: The creation is in the Dhataki forest and in the Mahavit forest.🔽Thus the continents are surrounded by seven oceans, each seven times larger than the one within.

analyzed: dvīpasya anantaraḥ yaḥ tu samudraḥ tad samaḥ tu vai
translated: The ocean immediately outside a continent is of the same size as the continent.

analyzed: evam dvīpa samudrāṇām vṛddhiḥ jñeyā parasparam
translated: Thus, the increase of the islands and oceans should be known to be mutual.

original: apāṃ caiva samudrekāt samudra iti saṃjñitaḥ // / //
analyzed: apām ca eva samudrekāt samudraḥ iti saṃjñitaḥ
translated: And because of the unity of the waters in the ocean, it is designated as the ocean.

analyzed: ṛṣat vasantyaḥ varṣeṣu prajāḥ yatra caturvidhāḥ
translated: In the rainy seasons, the four types of beings are born there.

analyzed: ramaṇe varṣantu etena teṣu vai

analyzed: pūrve tu samudraḥ pūryate sadā

analyzed: prakṣīyamāne bahule kṣīyate stamite ca vai

analyzed: āpūryamāṇaḥ hi udadhiḥ ātmanā eva abhipūryate

analyzed: tatas vai kṣīyamāṇe tu svātmani eva hi apām kṣayaḥ

analyzed: udayāt payasām yogāt āpaḥ yathā svayam
translated: The waters bloom by themselves due to the conjunction of the rising waters.

analyzed: tathā sa tu samudraḥ vardhate śaśinā udaye  anyūna anatirikta ātmā vardhanti āpaḥ hrasanti ca
translated: Thus, that ocean also increases with the rising of the moon.🔽The waters increase and decrease without any decrease or excess.

analyzed: udaye stamaye ca indoḥ pakṣayoḥ śukla kṛṣṇayoḥ
translated: At the rising and setting of the moon, in the bright and dark fortnights.

analyzed: kṣaya vṛddhī samudrasya śaśi vṛddhi kṣaye tathā
translated: The decrease and increase of the ocean are thus due to the increase and decrease of the moon.

analyzed: daśa uttarāṇi pañca āhuḥ aṅgulānām śatāni ca
translated: They say that there are five hundred and ten angulas.

analyzed: apām vṛddhiḥ kṣayaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ samudrāṇām tu parvasu

analyzed: nigīrṇa tvāt ca girayaḥ parva bandhāt ca parvatāḥ
translated: And because of being swallowed, they are mountains. And because of being bound by parvas (joints), they are mountains.

analyzed: śākadvīpe tu vai śākaḥ parvataḥ tena ca ucyate
translated: In Shakadvipa, there is a Shaka mountain. Therefore, it is called so.

analyzed: kuśadvīpe kuśa stambaḥ madhye janapadasya tu

analyzed: gomedake tu gomedaḥ parvataḥ tena ca ucyate
translated: In Gomedaka, there is a mountain called Gomedha. Therefore, it is called so.

analyzed: nyagrodhaḥ puṣkara dvīpe padmavat tena sa smṛtaḥ
translated: In Pushkaradvīpa, there is a Nyagrodha tree. It is known as Pushkara because of its lotus-like appearance.

analyzed: pūjyate sa mahā devaiḥ brahmā aṃśaḥ vyakta sambhavaḥ
translated: That great god, born from the unmanifest and a part of Brahmā, is worshipped there.

analyzed: sa tatra pūjyate devaḥ devaiḥ mahā ṛṣi sattamaiḥ

analyzed: jambūdvīpāt pravartante ratnāni vividhāni ca

original: dvīpeṣu teṣu sarveṣu prajānāṃ kramaśastu vai /

translated: In all those islands, the people gradually

translated: By straightforwardness, celibacy, truth, and self-control,

analyzed: dvīpeṣu teṣu sarveṣu yathoktam varṣakeṣu ca
translated: In all those islands and in the described years,

analyzed: bhojanam ca aprayatnena sadā svayam upasthitam

analyzed: ṣaṣ rasam tat mahā vīryam tatra te bhuñjate janāḥ
translated: Six flavors and great potency, there the people enjoy it.

analyzed: pareṇa puṣkarasya atha āvṛtya avasthitaḥ mahān
translated: Beyond that, surrounding Puṣkara, there is a great

analyzed: svādu udaka samudraḥ tu sa samantāt aveṣṭayat
translated: The Sweet Water Ocean surrounds it all.

analyzed: svādu udakasya paritas śailaḥ tu parimaṇḍalaḥ
translated: The mountain around the Sweet Water Ocean is circular,

analyzed: prakāśaḥ ca aprakāśaḥ ca lokālokaḥ saḥ ucyate
translated: It is called Lokāloka, both illuminated and unilluminated.

analyzed: ālokaḥ tatra ca arvāk ca nirālokaḥ tatas param
translated: Below that is the illuminated region, beyond that is the unilluminated region.

analyzed: praticchinnam samantāt tu udakena āvṛtam mahat

translated: and the wind circling horizontally, holding the elements,

analyzed: bhūtāditaḥ daśaguṇam mahat bhūtāni adhārayat
translated: The element of Mahat, ten times greater than the elements, held the space,

analyzed: mahat tattvam hi anantena avyaktena tu dhāryate  ādhāra ādheya bhāvena vikārāḥ te vikāriṇām
translated: and the Mahat principle is held by the infinite, the unmanifest.🔽The evolvents are the supports and the evolutes are the things supported.

analyzed: āsan te hi aviśeṣāḥ ca viśeṣāḥ anya veśanāt

analyzed: pṛthvī ādayaḥ tu vāyu antāḥ paricchinnāḥ tu tatra te

analyzed: bhūtebhyaḥ paratas tebhyaḥ hi alokaḥ sarvatas smṛtaḥ
translated: Beyond those elements, space is remembered as unlimited everywhere.

analyzed: tathā hi āloke ākāśe paricchinnāni sarvaśas
translated: For thus, space is completely limited in the sky.

original: pātre mahati pātrāṇi yathā hyantargatāni ca // / //
analyzed: pātre mahati pātrāṇi yathā hi antargatāni ca
translated: Just as the smaller vessels are contained within the larger vessel,

analyzed: bhavanti anyonya hīnāni paraspara samāśrayāt

analyzed: śatāni trīṇi ca anyāni trayastriṃśat tathā eva ca

analyzed: kāṣṭhayoḥ antaram hi etat yojanānām prakīrtitam

analyzed: tasmāt prakṛṣṭām bhūmim tu kālena alpena gacchati

analyzed: sūryaḥ dvādaśabhiḥ śīghram muhūrtaiḥ dakṣiṇāyane

analyzed: sūryaḥ ṣṭādaśabhiḥ ahnaḥ muhūrtaiḥ udagāyane  trayodaśānām madhye tu ṛkṣāṇām carate raviḥ

analyzed: muhūrtaiḥ triṃśatā tāvat ahorātram bhuvaḥ bhraman

analyzed: evam gati viśeṣeṇa vibhajan rātri ahāni tu

analyzed: etāvān eva lokaḥ tu nirālokaḥ tatas param

analyzed: lekhā prabhṛti atha āditye tri muhūrta āgate tu vai

analyzed: prātar smṛtaḥ tatas kālaḥ bhāgān ca āhuḥ ca pañca ca  tasmāt prātar gatāt kālāt muhūrtāḥ saṃgavaḥ trayaḥ

analyzed: caturdaśa ṛkṣeṣu śiśumāraḥ vyavasthitaḥ

analyzed: bhramantam anusarpanti nakṣatrāṇi ca cakra vat

analyzed: vāta anīka mayaiḥ bandhaiḥ dhruve baddhaḥ prasarpati

analyzed: viṣuvat graha varṇaḥ ca sarvam etat dhruva īritam
